introduction.p: The other case of particular importance will be matrices that behave like a rotation matrix: indeed, this will be crucial for understanding geometrically. See this .

In this section, we study in detail the situation when two matrices behave similarly with respect to different coordinate systems. In and , we will show how to use eigenvalues and eigenvectors to find a simpler matrix that behaves like a given matrix.

subsection.title: Similar Matrices
subsection.p: We begin with the algebraic definition of similarity.

statement.p: Two n\times n matrices A and B are similar if there exists an invertible n\times n matrix C such that A = CBC\inv.

example.p:
The matrices
\mat{-12 15; -10 13} \sptxt{and} \mat{3 0; 0 -2}
are similar because
\mat{-12 15; -10 13} = \mat{-2 3; 1 -1} \mat{3 0; 0 -2} \mat{-2 3; 1 -1}\inv,
as the reader can verify.

The matrices
\mat{3 0 ; 0 -2} \sptxt{and} \mat{1 0; 0 1}
are not similar. Indeed, the second matrix is the identity matrix I_2, so if C is any invertible 2\times 2 matrix, then
CI_2C\inv = CC\inv = I_2 \neq \mat{3 0; 0 -2}.

subsection.p: Similarityidentity matrix Identity matrixsimilarity As in the above example, one can show that I_n is the only matrix that is similar to I_n, and likewise for any scalar multiple of I_n.
As suggested by its name, similarity is what is called an equivalence relation. This means that it satisfies the following properties.

statement.p:
Let A,B, and C be n\times n matrices.
Reflexivity: A is similar to itself.
Symmetry: if A is similar to B, then B is similar to A.
Transitivity: if A is similar to B and B is similar to C, then A is similar to C.

ol.li: Taking C = I_n = I_n\inv, we have A = I_n A I_n\inv.

Suppose that A = CBC\inv. Multiplying both sides on the left by C\inv and on the right by C gives
C\inv A C = C\inv(CBC\inv)C = B.
Since (C\inv)\inv = C, we have B = C\inv A (C\inv)\inv, so that B is similar to A.

Suppose that A = DBD\inv and B = ECE\inv. Subsituting for B and remembering that (DE)\inv = E\inv D\inv, we have
A = D(ECE\inv)D\inv = (DE)C(DE)\inv,
which shows that A is similar to C.

subsection.p: We conclude with an observation about similarity and powers of matrices.

statement.p: Let A = CBC\inv. Then for any n\geq 1, we have A^n = CB^n C\inv.

proof.p:
First note that
A^2 = AA = (CBC\inv)(CBC\inv) = CB(C\inv C)BC\inv = CBI_nBC\inv = CB^2C\inv.
Next we have
A^3 = A^2A = (CB^2C\inv)(CBC\inv) = CB^2(C\inv C)BC\inv = CB^3C\inv.
The pattern is clear.

solution.p:
By the , we have
A^{100} = \mat{-2 3; 1 -1}\mat{0 -1; 1 0}^{100}\mat{-2 3; 1 -1}\inv.
The matrix \smallmat 0{-1}10 is a counterclockwise rotation by 90^\circ. If we rotate by 90^\circ four times, then we end up where we started. Hence rotating by 90^\circ one hundred times is the identity transformation, so
A^{100} = \mat{-2 3; 1 -1}\mat{1 0; 0 1}\mat{-2 3; 1 -1}\inv = \mat{1 0; 0 1}.

subsection.title: Geometry of Similar Matrices
subsection.p: Similarity is a very interesting construction when viewed geometrically. We will see that, roughly, similar matrices do the same thing in different coordinate systems. The reader might want to review \cB-coordinates and nonstandard coordinate grids in before reading this subsection.

By conditions 4 and 5 of the , an n\times n matrix C is invertible if and only if its columns v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_n form a basis for \R^n. This means we can speak of the \cB-coordinates of a vector in \R^n, where \cB is the basis of columns of C. Recall that
[x]_\cB = \vec{c_1 c_2 \vdots, c_n} \sptxt{means} x = c_1v_1 + c_2v_2 + \cdots + c_nv_n = \mat{| | ,, |; v_1 v_2 \cdots, v_n; | | ,, |}\vec{c_1 c_2 \vdots, c_n}.
Since C is the matrix with columns v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_n, this says that x = C[x]_\cB. Multiplying both sides by C\inv gives [x]_\cB = C\inv x. To summarize:

bluebox.p:
Let C be an invertible n\times n matrix with columns v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_n, and let \cB = \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_n\}, a basis for \R^n. Then for any x in \R^n, we have
C[x]_\cB = x \sptxt{and} C\inv x = [x]_\cB.
This says that C changes from the \cB-coordinates to the usual coordinates, and C\inv changes from the usual coordinates to the \cB-coordinates.

subsection.p: Suppose that A = CBC\inv. The above observation gives us another way of computing Ax for a vector x in \R^n. Recall that CBC\inv x = C(B(C\inv x)), so that multiplying CBC\inv by x means first multiplying by C\inv, then by B, then by C. See this .

bluebox.p: To summarize: if A = CBC\inv, then A and B do the same thing, only in different coordinate systems.

bluebox.title: A Matrix Similar to a Rotation Matrix

example.title: Interactive: Similar 3\times 3 matrices
example.p:
Consider the matrices
A = \mat{-1 0 0; -1 0 2; -1 1 1} \qquad B = \mat{-1 0 0; 0 -1 0; 0 0 2} \qquad C = \mat{-1 1 0; 1 1 1; -1 0 1}.
Then A = CBC\inv, as one can verify. Let v_1,v_2,v_3 be the columns of C, and let \cB = \{v_1,v_2,v_3\}, a basis of \R^3. Then A does the same thing as B, except A uses the \cB-coordinate system. In other words:
B scales the e_1,e_2-plane by -1 and the e_3-direction by 2.
A scales the v_1,v_2-plane by -1 and the v_3-direction by 2.

subsection.title: Eigenvalues of Similar Matrices
subsection.p: Since similar matrices behave in the same way with respect to different coordinate systems, we should expect their eigenvalues and eigenvectors to be closely related.

statement.p: Similar matrices have the same characteristic polynomial.

proof.p:
Suppose that A = CBC\inv, where A,B,C are n\times n matrices. We calculate
\begin{split} A - \lambda I_n \amp= CBC\inv - \lambda CC\inv = CBC\inv - C\lambda C\inv \\ \amp= CBC\inv - C\lambda I_n C\inv = C(B-\lambda I_n)C\inv. \end{split}
Therefore,
\det(A-\lambda I_n) = \det(C(B-\lambda I_n)C\inv) = \det(C)\det(B-\lambda I_n)\det(C)\inv = \det(B-\lambda I_n).
Here we have used the multiplicativity property and its corollary.

subsection.p: Since the eigenvalues of a matrix are the roots of its characteristic polynomial, we have shown:

bluebox.p: Similar matrices have the same eigenvalues.

subsection.p: Similarityand the trace Similarityand the determinant Determinantof similar matrices Matrixtrace ofsimilar matrices By this , similar matrices also have the same trace and determinant.

Given that similar matrices have the same eigenvalues, one might guess that they have the same eigenvectors as well. Upon reflection, this is not what one should expect: indeed, the eigenvectors should only match up after changing from one coordinate system to another. This is the content of the next fact, remembering that C and C\inv change between the usual coordinates and the \cB-coordinates.

proof.p: Suppose that v is an eigenvector of A with eigenvalue \lambda, so that Av = \lambda v. Then B(C\inv v) = C\inv(CBC\inv v) = C\inv(Av) = C\inv\lambda v = \lambda(C\inv v), so that C\inv v is an eigenvector of B with eigenvalue \lambda. Likewise if v is an eigenvector of B with eigenvalue \lambda, then Bv = \lambda v, and we have A(Cv) = (CBC\inv)Cv = CBv = C(\lambda v) = \lambda(Cv), so that Cv is an eigenvalue of A with eigenvalue \lambda.

bluebox.p: If A = CBC\inv, then C\inv takes the \lambda-eigenspace of A to the \lambda-eigenspace of B, and C takes the \lambda-eigenspace of B to the \lambda-eigenspace of A.

example.title: Interactive: Similar 3\times 3 matrices
example.p:
Continuing with this , let
A = \mat{-1 0 0; -1 0 2; -1 1 1} \qquad B = \mat{-1 0 0; 0 -1 0; 0 0 2} \qquad C = \mat{-1 1 0; 1 1 1; -1 0 1},
so A = CBC\inv. Let v_1,v_2,v_3 be the columns of C. Then:
B scales the e_1,e_2-plane by -1 and the e_3-direction by 2.
A scales the v_1,v_2-plane by -1 and the v_3-direction by 2.
In other words, the xy-plane is the -1-eigenspace of B, and the z-axis is the 2-eigenspace of B; likewise, the v_1,v_2-plane is the -1-eigenspace of A, and the v_3-axis is the 2-eigenspace of A. This is consistent with the , as multiplication by C changes e_1 into Ce_1 = v_1, e_2 into Ce_2 = v_2, and e_3 into Ce_3 = v_3.
